awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Evolutionary Consequences of Climate Change: Testing key hypotheses in a montane mustard
awd_abstract_narration:
This research tests whether plants will be able to survive on a warming planet using a mustard plant species as a model. Climate change threatens the persistence of many organisms worldwide. Vulnerable species must adapt or migrate to avoid extinction. Species such as plants that are unable to move will face particular challenges when coping with rapid changes in climate. In the meadows of the wildflower capital of Colorado, natural communities of plants are confronting hotter and drier conditions. Drummond's rockcress (Boechera stricta) is native to the Rocky Mountains and can grow at elevations as low as 5,000 feet and higher than 12,000 feet in sites as far north as Alaska and as far south as Arizona. The climate varies dramatically across this broad range, and rockcress plants have developed adaptations that enable them to perform best in their home sites. But can they adapt to the current pace of climate change quickly enough to survive? This research combines large-scale field studies with laboratory experiments to ask whether natural populations have enough genetic diversity to adapt in the short-term to rapidly changing conditions. Populations or species with limited adaptive potential may have to be relocated to more hospitable areas to conserve biodiversity. This project engages high school students, future high school teachers, and undergraduate researchers in the scientific method, increasing scientific literacy, and career opportunities.

Field and laboratory studies use the ecological model species B. stricta to examine: (1) how short-term fitness consequences of climate change influence the migratory and adaptive potential of populations; and (2) how plasticity, adaptation, and gene flow contribute to longer-term population persistence. To achieve these aims, researchers will evaluate how snow pack dynamics and temperatures interact to shape adaptation in nature, analyze the direct and indirect effects of climate on fitness and optimal phenotypes, assess clinal variation in local adaptation, and investigate the stability of the genetic covariance matrix in multiple environments.

por.por_cntn:
Climate change has reshaped the environment that plants and animals encounter in nature. The ecological consequences of climate change are quite clear. Many species can no longer live across the full expanse of their historical conditions. Populations have gone locally extinct in the warmer portions of the range, and some have expanded into the cooler portions. Additionally, plants and animals have altered the timing of critical events like reproduction. This study aimed to fill in critical gaps in our understanding of how climate change is altering evolution of a native plant. Specifically, this project yielded novel insights into how climate change disrupts long-standing patterns of natural selection and local adaptation. Furthermore, this project found that local populations may not have enough genetic variation to adapt to novel conditions.

This project focused on Drummond’s rockcress (Boechera stricta), a perennial plant native to the Rocky Mountains where it is abundant in rocky meadows and streamsides. This species now flowers more than two weeks earlier in the year than it did in the 1970s because climate change has advanced the timing of spring. We have conducted field experiments in Colorado and laboratory studies at the University of Georgia. Over the course of this project, we have transplanted >180,000 individuals into various treatments that reflect climate change projections into five experimental gardens at different elevations in Colorado.

We have found that Drummond’s rockcress is adapted to historical climates, and that climate change disrupts plant performance and other characteristics. Our field and laboratory studies have demonstrated that plants do best in temperature, drought, and snow regimes that reflect the historical climate. Results from this project led to the critical discovery that local populations are now poorly adapted to current climates in their home sites and that climate change further reduces the performance of local populations. By exposing experimental plants to historical climates, we found that local genotypes once again had optimal fitness in their home sites. This result suggests that climate change could jeopardize the persistence of local populations, even in common widely distributed species, like B. stricta. Indeed, our field experiment revealed  that populations from the three lowest elevation sites are at a severe risk of local extinction. Conservation methods, such as the assisted migration, could be necessary to stabilize populations and reduce the risk of loss of genetic diversity.

In addition to investigating evolution in response to climate change, these studies have found that individuals can alter their traits in response to climatic variation through phenotypic plasticity, that selection varies across space and time, and that climate change may shorten the lifespan of plants.

Over the course of the project, we have published 22 peer-reviewed papers and two commentaries based on the results of this work. We anticipate that at least another five publications will emerge from the data collected across the course of this project. We have published all data and statistical code for other researchers to use freely. In addition, we have presented 39 talks to primarily to scientific audiences, although several talks have been to the public.

Broader Impacts: One major goal of this project is to create educational opportunities for high school students, undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral associates, as well as professional development opportunities for prospective secondary school educators. As such, this project has funded the training of three postdoctoral scholars, five Ph.D. students, 64 undergraduate and recently graduated students, six high school researchers, and one middle school researcher. In addition, we have collaborated with high school teachers to teach a two-week field ecology course to 12-15 high school students every summer of this project. We have designed a rigorous 80 contact hour class that allows students to earn a full semester of high school science credit through the Gunnison County Schools, or college credit through Western State Colorado University. Over the course of this project, we have conducted professional development activities for 2-5 high school teachers and prospective teachers per year to engage with the field ecology course (16 teachers total). This NSF grant has supported 19 students to attend this course. Finally, we have developed modules for undergrad and grad classes to analyze data collected over the course of the project and don extensive outreach, ranging from working with K-12 students to writing for the Athens Science Observer, which is a local publication for graduate students to write about science for the general public.
